title.value: Generalizing across Temporal Domains with Koopman Operators
title.justification: This is the obvious title of the paper.
title.quote: Generalizing across Temporal Domains with Koopman Operators

extractions.description: The paper addresses the challenge of constructing predictive models capable of generalizing to a target domain without accessing target data, particularly in the context of evolving dynamics between domains. It proposes the use of Koopman Neural Operators to solve the Temporal Domain Generalization (TDG) problem and introduces Temporal Koopman Networks (TKNets) to handle time-evolving distributions effectively. The approach is validated through empirical evaluations on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical evaluations conducted on synthetic and real-world datasets, validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach, Temporal Koopman Networks (TKNets).
type.quote: Through empirical evaluations conducted on synthetic and real-world datasets, we validate the effectiveness of our proposed approach.

name.justification: The paper focuses on solving the Temporal Domain Generalization (TDG) problem.
The paper distinguishes TDG from Temporal Domain Adaptation and discusses why existing domain adaptation methods cannot be directly applied to TDG.
name.quote: Here, we emphasize the key difference between Temporal Domain Generalization (Bai, Ling, and Zhao 2022; Nasery et al. 2021; Qin, Wang, and Li 2022) and Temporal Domain Adaptation (Kim et al. 2020; Liu et al. 2020; Wang, He, and Katabi 2020).

name.justification: The paper builds on Koopman theory and proposes Temporal Koopman Networks (TKNets) to address the evolving dynamics in TDG.
name.quote: Our theoretical results are based on proposed λ-consistency, an intuitive and realistic measurement of evolving levels in the environments.

name.justification: Temporal Koopman Networks (TKNets) are introduced by the authors as a new model for solving the TDG problem.
name.quote: we propose a novel algorithm TKNets, which learns the complex and non-linear dynamics based on Koopman theory;

name.justification: RMNIST is mentioned as a benchmark dataset in the domain generalization literature and is used for evaluating the proposed TKNets.
name.quote: For example, it is common that source domains are constituted of images collected over the last few years and the target domain is the unseen future. For geological applications, the source samples can be collected along different altitudes, longitude, and latitude, while the target is to generalize to some regions where the data is absent due to inaccessibility. Medical data is also often collected with age or other indicators as intervals, and we hope the model can perform well on younger or elder age groups where the samples may be rare.
